Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2010 08:30PM - edited Aug 2, 2010 08:31PM by montana7p Hi Amy - I don't have any good insight -- but thought I'd let you know you're not alone.  I had a BMX, expanders/implants, axillary dissection on the R, radiation on the R.  About 7 months after finishing chemo, 6 months after surgery and 4 months after radiation, I started getting numbness in my index finger and thumb on my right hand.  It has progressively gotten worse to where the tips of my middle ring and pinky are also numb.  I'm having trouble doing certain things with my RH (picking up small things, typing, putting on a necklace, opening jars, etc.).  I mention it to oncology type doctors and I get mostly nothing more than a hmmmm (they're so concerned about your boobs looking good - which mine do I have to say, but I actually USE my right hand on a daily basis).  I did get a prescription for physical therapy and two therapists and one of my oncologists has diagnosed it as carpel tunnel.  Did I mention I've worked less than I ever have in the past year and a half and actually had three months off from working in the past 5 months.  Why on earth would it be carpal tunnel? I'm inclined to think it's something related to surgery or radiation -- scar tissue impinging on something, radiation damage, shoulder shifting from tightness from surgery and impinging on a nerve.  I'm making all of this up, but carpal tunnel just doesn't make sense to me.  I'd be interested in knowing if you get anywhere.  The numbness in my fingers is really annoying.

I know there is a hormonal therapy thread, but I thought I'd post this here since it seems that the recommendation for supression is based on the aggressive nature and staging of my diagnosis. Is this a clear-cut choice for me? Any words of wisdom from those having been in the same boat are appreciated. Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2009 06:54PM montana7p wrote: Hi Bluebird71 - I finished 32 rads on Aug. 27.  My skin was super red, itchy, blistering under my arm, peeling -- exactly as you describe. My radiation oncologist perscribed the domeboro soak 3-4 x per day and then either using aquaphor or 100% hydrous lanolin (very gooey and sticky) as the only other topical treatments 2-3x/day. In retrospect, I think what makes it heal is a little bit of time. I'd say I was pretty uncomfortable for about two weeks. Now, on Sept. 13, I am happy to report that the only way I'd know is from the suntan outline. My radiation oncologist offered vidocin for sleeping and if it was really bothering me during the day. I took it on and off for about a week. So, hang in there while you're all red. Mine really started to turn the corner about a week after the rads were finished and healed pretty quickly after that. You can do it!
